data.title: Earnings Snapshot: Medical Properties Trust misses Q3 revenue estimate; FFO in-line
Stock index futures fall as Meta, Microsoft results leave investors unimpressed
data.description:
Stock index futures fell on Thursday, as investors were left unimpressed by Meta (META) and Microsoft (MSFT) results. Traders were now geared up for Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) earnings and assessed the latest updates of the U.S.-China trade talks.

S&P 500 futures (SPX) -0.2%, Nasdaq 100 futures (US100:IND) -0.3%, and Dow futures (INDU) -0.3%.

U.S. President Donald Trump announced a one-year agreement with China covering rare earths and critical minerals, while also halving fentanyl-related tariffs on Beijing (from 20% to 10%), effective immediately, following his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in South Korea on Thursday.

"The U.S. (though not yet China) announced a year-long Sino-U.S. trade agreement. The details have to be worked out. Markets are likely to be cheered, but not wildly enthusiastic," UBS' Paul Donovan said. 

Traders and investors watched markets end the day mixed on Wednesday after the FOMC announced a 25-basis-point rate cut.

The Fed reduced its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.75%-4.00%, its second straight cut, as it seeks to ease off the brakes in an effort to protect the labor market.

"On rates policy, our economists maintain a baseline of a 25 bps rate cut in December but see the hawkish-leaning signal as consistent with their view of fundamentals pointing to fewer rate cuts than priced by markets," Deutsche Bank's Jim Reid said. 

"The Fed spoke with an almost British accent yesterday, cutting rates a quarter point with a Bank of England-like three-way vote split. Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaled that a December cut was not inevitable," Donovan said.

Wednesday also saw a slew of tech companies report their earnings, namely Microsoft (MSFT), Alphabet (GOOG)(GOOGL) and Meta (META). 

Meta Platforms (META) was down 7.1% in a premarket trade as it recorded a one-time income tax charge of nearly $16B and also raised its full-year guidance for total expenses.

Class A shares (GOOGL) of Alphabet rose 6.7%, while class C shares (GOOG) also added 6.7% premarket as the firm delivered its first-ever quarter with $100B in revenue, while its AI assistant Gemini app hit over 650M monthly active users.

Microsoft (MSFT) was down 3.1% even after it topped quarterly expectations, though its investments in ChatGPT developer OpenAI hit its profit.

"Then after the market close, we saw results from Microsoft, Meta, and Alphabet send contrasting signals on the payoffs from the AI investment boom. The three tech giants saw their joint capex bill rise 89% Y/Y to $78B in the latest quarter," Reid said.

In the day ahead, traders will get more tech earnings, with Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) set to report after the closing bell.

data.title: Hansa Biopharma GAAP EPS of -SEK1.75, revenue of SEK 30.8M
data.description:
• Hansa Biopharma press release (HNSBF): Q3 GAAP EPS of -SEK 1.75.
  • Revenue of SEK 30.8M (-36.8% Y/Y).
  • Year to date IDEFIRIX product sales totalled 143.6 MSEK and represented an increase of 29.1 MSEK or 25.4% compared to the same period a year ago (114.5 MSEK).
  • Year to date product sales represent approximately 102% of total full-year product sales achieved in 2024.
  • Product sales in the third quarter of 2025 totalled 30.1 MSEK, compared to 39.8 MSEK for the same period in 2024.

data.title: Mastercard in Charts: Worldwide GDV and Transactions up ~10% Y/Y in Q3, while Cross-border volume jumps 19%
S&P Global raises 2025 guidance after Q3 earnings, revenue beat
data.description:
S&P Global (SPGI) shares drifted up 2.4% in Thursday premarket trading after the credit-ratings, market index, and data company upwardly revised its full-year guidance on the heels of stronger-than-expected Q3 results.

The firm now expects 2025 adjusted EPS of $17.60-$17.85 (midpoint $17.725), surpassing the $17.28 average analyst estimate and up from $17.00$17.25 (midpoint $17.13) in the previous target. Revenue growth for the year is expected to be 7%-8% (midpoint 7.5%), vs. +6.9% consensus and 5%-7% (midpoint 6%) in the earlier goal.

Meanwhile, "S&P Global delivered exceptional financial results in the third quarter, with accelerating revenue growth andsignificant margin expansion," President and CEO Martina Cheung said in a statement.

Q3 adjusted EPS of $4.73, topping the $4.41 consensus, advanced from $4.43 in Q2 and $3.89 a year ago.

Q3 revenue of $3.89B, also beating the $3.83 expected, climbed from $3.76 in the previous quarter and +9% Y/Y.

By segment, Market Intelligence revenue of $1.24B vs. $1.22B in Q2 and $1.16B in Q3 2024; Ratings revenue of $1.24B vs. $1.15B in Q2 and $1.11B in last year's Q3; Commodity Insights revenue of $556M vs. $555M in Q2 and $522M in Q3 2024; Mobility revenue of $445M vs. $438M in Q2 and $412M a year ago; and Indices revenue of $462M vs. $446M in Q2 and $416M last year.

Expenses totaled $2.22B, holding steady from the prior three-month period and rising from $2.17B in Q3 2024.

Since July, S&P Global (SPGI) has returned $1.5B to shareholders via dividends and share buybacks, it said. The company expects to implement additional repurchases totaling $2.5B in Q4.

data.title: InterDigital Non-GAAP EPS of $2.55 beats by $0.50, revenue of $164.7M beats by $11.35M
data.description:
• InterDigital press release (IDCC): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of $2.55 beats by $0.50.
  • Revenue of $164.7M (+28.0% Y/Y) beats by $11.35M.
  • Outstanding total portfolio of $1.1 billion, composed of 88 investments3
  • Single-family rental ("SFR"), multifamily, life sciences, self-storage and marinas represent 15.9%, 47.3%, 33.9%, 1.8% and 1.1% of the Company's investment portfolio, respectively as of September 30, 2025
  • Weighted-average loan to value ("LTV")4 and debt service coverage ratio ("DSCR") on our senior loans, CMBS, CMBS I/O strips, preferred equity, and mezzanine investments are 54.9% and 1.41x3, respectively
  • During 3Q 2025, NREF purchased $42.5MM of preferred stock
  • During the quarter, the Company funded $6.5MM on a loan that pays a monthly coupon of SOFR + 900 bps.

data.title: KLA Corp. in focus as Wall Street praises after strong Q1 results, guidance
data.description:
KLA Corp. (KLAC) was in focus on Thursday as a number of Wall Street firms praised the semiconductor equipment firm after it reported stronger-than-expected first-quarter results and guidance. 

Shares erased losses after the company reported and rose fractionally in premarket trading.

“KLAC reported F1Q results and F2Q guide slightly ahead of consensus, but took a positive tone on the call, saying accelerating AI investment is driving demand in compute, memory and advanced packaging, and increasing customer engagement beyond the leading foundry,” KeyBanc analyst Steve Barger wrote in a note to clients. “That bullish commentary was tempered by some uncertainty in ramp timing which depends on clean room & new fab space availability. We expect consensus estimates to increase, but perhaps not enough in the [near-term] to support recent multiple expansion. Maintain [Sector-Weight].” 

Stifel analyst Brian Chin said that even though KLA Corp. guided better than Wall Street's forecast despite weakness in China is impressive. 

“Pull-ins from HBM/DRAM-led memory is expected to offset China in the DecQ, into next year. On track to grow revenue +17% in CY25, KLA reiterated higher [wafer fab equipment] spend next year, with calendar 1H26 revenue at similar-higher levels, then accelerating in the backhalf (not too dissimilar to peers),” Chin wrote in a note to clients. 

He continued: “We view KLA as warranting a premium to the broader market based on its track record of delivering consistent, high-quality revenue growth over time.” Chin raised his price target to $1,260 from $1,050 and reiterated his Buy rating on KLA Corp.

data.title: KB Financial reports Q3 results
data.description:
• KB Financial press release (KB): Q3 Profit for the period of WON5.1B
  • Revenue of WON9.7T (+1.3% Y/Y).

data.title: BorgWarner secures multiple new contracts
data.description:
• BorgWarner (BWA) has secured multiple contracts with Chery to supply advanced all-wheel drive (AWD) technologies, including its torque-on-demand transfer case with mechanical lock (Mlock TOD) and Gen VI Cross Wheel Drive (XWD) system. 
  • Mass production is scheduled to begin in 2027, the company said on Thursday.
  • Furthermore, the company has also secured a contract to supply its 7-in-1 Integrated Drive Module (iDM) to a leading Chinese OEM.
  • BorgWarner (BWA) reported another contract win to supply its battery system to the all-new HOLON urban, a 15-person, Level 4 autonomous, fully electric shuttle.
  • The contract marks BorgWarner's first supply of battery technology for autonomous vehicles produced in North America.

data.title: Howmet Aerospace stock dips on guidance for slower revenue growth
data.description:
Howmet Aerospace (HWM) shares fell 1.7% in premarket trading Thursday after the aerospace components manufacturer provided guidance for slower revenue growth.

The company’s 2026 revenue outlook of roughly $9 billion, up about 10% year over year, marks a slowdown from its current 14% growth rate. The guidance is in line with the consensus estimate.

Howmet (HWM) projected fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of $0.94 to $0.96 a share, compared with Wall Street’s estimate of $0.94, and reaffirmed a 2025 adjusted ebitda margin of 29%.

During the third quarter, the company posted net income of $385 million, or $0.95 a share, up from $332 million, or $0.81 a share, in the same period a year earlier. That beat Wall Street’s earnings estimate of $0.91 a share.

Adjusted earnings also came in at $0.95 per share, beating the consensus forecast of $0.91 a share.

Revenue rose 14% to $2.09 billion, topping analyst estimates of $2.04 billion, driven by growth across commercial and defense aerospace, and industrial markets.

Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization rose 26% year over year to $614 million, with margins expanding 290 basis points to 29.4%, reflecting strong performance in the company’s Engine Products and Fastening Systems segments.

Chief Executive Officer John Plant in a statement called it “a very strong quarter” that exceeded the high end of guidance across all metrics, highlighting free cash flow of $423 million and a 20% dividend increase.

Still, despite the earnings beat, investors appeared cautious after

Howmet’s commercial transportation business, which declined 3% year over year, continued to lag its other segments, signaling persistent softness in that market even as aerospace demand remains robust.

The company repurchased $200 million of stock during the quarter and another $100 million in October, bringing total 2025 buybacks to $600 million. It also paid down $63 million in debt and received a credit-rating upgrade to BBB+ from S&P Global.

Plant reaffirmed confidence in the company’s transformation, noting that “air traffic continues to grow and the backlog of commercial aircraft extends through the decade,” but he acknowledged “ongoing weakness in commercial transportation” that could weigh on near-term performance.
